# Labels & factors {#lab_fct} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) pend_kap5 <- haven::read_dta("./orig/PENDDAT_cf_W13.dta", col_select = c("pnr","welle", "zpsex", "PSM0100","azges1","palter")) %>% filter(welle == 8, palter > 0,azges1 > 0) ``` ::: ## Labels from Other Programs in R In many software packages like Stata or SPSS, labels are often retained through various operations and then displayed automatically. This is not the case in R. Instead, in R, we can assign labels using the `factor` variable type. This approach might seem unusual for those who have worked extensively with Stata or SPSS, but it is quite useful in practice if you get accustomed to the workflow. Generally, you *can* use value labels from other software packages in are. For example, when we create a count summary with `count()`, the labels from the `.dta`-file are displayed: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Counting occurrences and showing labels pend_kap5 %>% count(PSM0100) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 2 PSM0100 n 1 -5 [Does not use the internet] 28 2 1 [Yes] 318 3 2 [No] 337 ``` ::: ::: These are assigned as `attributes()` variables: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} attributes(pend_kap5$PSM0100) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $label [1] "Usage of social networks" $format.stata [1] "%39.0f" $labels Item not surveyed in wave Does not use the internet Details refused -9 -5 -2 Don't know Yes No -1 1 2 $class [1] "haven_labelled" "vctrs_vctr" "double" ``` ::: ::: `enframe()` from the `{tibble}` (part of the `{tidyverse}`) package helps to get data.frame with an overview of all value labels stored in an attribute: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} attributes(pend_kap5$PSM0100)$labels %>% enframe(value = "variable_value",name = "label") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 2 label variable_value 1 Item not surveyed in wave -9 2 Does not use the internet -5 3 Details refused -2 4 Don't know -1 5 Yes 1 6 No 2 ``` ::: ::: However, managing attributes() is tedious and sometimes causes problems when working with the labelled variables. R's native way to work with labels are `factor` variables. As mentioned in chapter 2, `factor` variables are strings with a predefined universe and ordering. How can we use the `attributes()`-labels as `factor` to save typing? `{haven}` includes the function `as_factor`[^2], which allows us to directly create a `factor` variable from labels: [^2]: Not to be confused with `as.factor()` from base R – the `_` makes a difference! ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pend_kap5$PSM0100_fct <- as_factor(pend_kap5$PSM0100) # create factor variable from attributes and values # view: pend_kap5 %>% select(contains("PSM0100")) %>% head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 2 PSM0100 PSM0100_fct 1 2 [No] No 2 1 [Yes] Yes 3 2 [No] No 4 -5 [Does not use the internet] Does not use the internet 5 -5 [Does not use the internet] Does not use the internet 6 -5 [Does not use the internet] Does not use the internet ``` ::: ::: ## Creating or editing `factor` manually Alternatively, we can also label with `factor()` using the `levels` and `labels` options ourselves. The `labels` are assigned in order to the numbers from `levels`. Additionally, all unspecified `levels` automatically become `NA`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pend_kap5$PSM0100_fct2 <- factor(pend_kap5$PSM0100, levels = c(1,2), labels = c("Yes!","No :-(")) # view: pend_kap5 %>% select(contains("PSM0100")) %>% head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 3 PSM0100 PSM0100_fct PSM0100_fct2 1 2 [No] No No :-( 2 1 [Yes] Yes Yes! 3 2 [No] No No :-( 4 -5 [Does not use the internet] Does not use the internet 5 -5 [Does not use the internet] Does not use the internet 6 -5 [Does not use the internet] Does not use the internet ``` ::: ::: Or we can use the functions from `{forcats}` to recode a `factor`. `{forcats}` is part of the `{tidyverse}`. With `fct_recode()`, we can change the `levels`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} levels(pend_kap5$PSM0100_fct) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Item not surveyed in wave" "Does not use the internet" [3] "Details refused" "Don't know" [5] "Yes" "No" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} pend_kap5$PSM0100_fct3 <- fct_recode(pend_kap5$PSM0100_fct, `Uses social networks` = "Yes", # use `` around words with spaces ) levels(pend_kap5$PSM0100_fct3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Item not surveyed in wave" "Does not use the internet" [3] "Details refused" "Don't know" [5] "Uses social networks" "No" ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pend_kap5 %>% select(contains("PSM0100")) %>% head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 4 PSM0100 PSM0100_fct PSM0100_fct2 PSM0100_fct3 1 2 [No] No No :-( No 2 1 [Yes] Yes Yes! Uses social… 3 2 [No] No No :-( No 4 -5 [Does not use the internet] Does not use the int… Does not us… 5 -5 [Does not use the internet] Does not use the int… Does not us… 6 -5 [Does not use the internet] Does not use the int… Does not us… ``` ::: ::: More `fct_....()` functions from `{forcats}` can be found in this [Cheatsheet](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rstudio/cheatsheets/main/factors.pdf). ## Exercise ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pend_ue5 <- haven::read_dta("./orig/PENDDAT_cf_W13.dta", col_select = c("pnr","welle","PD0400")) %>% filter(PD0400>0) ``` ::: Edit the *value labels* of `PD0400`: Religiousness, self-rating ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: + First, use `head()` and a count with `count()` to get an overview. + How can you use the labels from the `attributes()` with `as_factor()` to create a variable `PD0400_fct`? + Create a `factor()` variable `F411_01_fct2` with *value labels*: `1 = Not at all`, `2 = Rather not`, `3 = Rather yes`, `4 = Very much` **Bonus exercise:** Use the labeled variable for a bar chart. ## Appendix ### Remove labels with `zap_...` from `{haven}` The label `attributes()` often cause problems in further processing. With `haven::zap_labels()`, we can remove value labels from a dataset, and with `haven::zap_label()`, we can remove variable labels. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pend_kap5 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 683 × 6 pnr welle zpsex PSM0100 azges1 palter 1 1000002601 8 [Wave 8 (2014)] 2 [Female] 2 [No] 22 34 2 1000010402 8 [Wave 8 (2014)] 2 [Female] 1 [Yes] 40 30 3 1000019102 8 [Wave 8 (2014)] 1 [Male] 2 [No] 40 34 4 1000031403 8 [Wave 8 (2014)] 1 [Male] -5 [Does not use the i… 44 52 5 1000032801 8 [Wave 8 (2014)] 2 [Female] -5 [Does not use the i… 44 58 6 1000032802 8 [Wave 8 (2014)] 1 [Male] -5 [Does not use the i… 43 62 7 1000038201 8 [Wave 8 (2014)] 1 [Male] 1 [Yes] 43 61 8 1000040003 8 [Wave 8 (2014)] 1 [Male] 2 [No] 36 40 9 1000051801 8 [Wave 8 (2014)] 2 [Female] 2 [No] 31 44 10 1000053101 8 [Wave 8 (2014)] 1 [Male] 1 [Yes] 27 47 # ℹ 673 more rows ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} pend_kap5 %>% haven::zap_labels() # remove value labels ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 683 × 6 pnr welle zpsex PSM0100 azges1 palter 1 1000002601 8 2 2 22 34 2 1000010402 8 2 1 40 30 3 1000019102 8 1 2 40 34 4 1000031403 8 1 -5 44 52 5 1000032801 8 2 -5 44 58 6 1000032802 8 1 -5 43 62 7 1000038201 8 1 1 43 61 8 1000040003 8 1 2 36 40 9 1000051801 8 2 2 31 44 10 1000053101 8 1 1 27 47 # ℹ 673 more rows ``` ::: ::: ### Creating labels in R and exporting to Stata If we want to label a dataset for Stata, for example, `{labelled}` comes in handy again: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} fdz_install("labelled") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(labelled) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in library(labelled): es gibt kein Paket namens 'labelled' ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pend_kap5$zpsex_num2 <- as.numeric(pend_kap5$zpsex) attributes(pend_kap5$zpsex_num2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` NULL ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} val_labels(pend_kap5$zpsex_num2) <- c("Männer Testtesttest"=1,"Frauen"=2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in val_labels(pend_kap5$zpsex_num2) <- c(`Männer Testtesttest` = 1, : konnte Funktion "val_labels<-" nicht finden ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} attributes(pend_kap5$zpsex_num2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` NULL ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} pend_kap5 %>% count(zpsex_num2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 × 2 zpsex_num2 n 1 1 324 2 2 359 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pend_kap5 %>% select(zpsex_num2) %>% haven::write_dta(.,path = "./data/pend_kap5.dta") ``` ::: ...in *Stata*: ::: {.cell} ```{.stata .cell-code} use "./data/pend_kap5.dta" tab zpsex_num2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` zpsex_num2 | Freq. Percent Cum. ------------+----------------------------------- 1 | 324 47.44 47.44 2 | 359 52.56 100.00 ------------+----------------------------------- Total | 683 100.00 ``` ::: ::: [More on `labels` in `{labelled}`](https://joseph.larmarange.net/intro_labelled.html).
